title: Transition Guide: Starting Your Journey at CMU Africa
introduction: Welcome to Kigali! This guide will help you navigate your first weeks at CMU Africa and settle into life in Rwanda's capital city.

content.subtitle: On-Campus Housing
content.description: CMU Africa provides on-campus accommodation for first-year students. Rooms are furnished with a bed, desk, wardrobe, and high-speed internet.
tips: Apply for housing as soon as you receive your acceptance letter
On-campus housing includes utilities and internet
Shared kitchen facilities are available on each floor
24/7 security and maintenance support

content.subtitle: Off-Campus Options
content.description: Many upperclassmen choose to live off-campus for more independence and often lower costs.
tips: Popular neighborhoods: Kimihurura, Kacyiru, Nyarutarama (close to campus)
Expected rent: $200-600/month depending on location and amenities
Always visit in person before signing a lease
Negotiate! Prices are often flexible, especially for longer leases
Utilities may or may not be included - clarify before signing
resources: Facebook groups: 'Housing in Kigali', 'CMU Africa Housing'
Local agents: Real Estate Rwanda, Pam Golding Properties
Connect with current students for roommate opportunities

content.subtitle: Banking
content.description: Setting up a local bank account makes life much easier.
tips: Recommended banks: Bank of Kigali, I&M Bank, Equity Bank (student-friendly)
Required documents: Passport, student ID, proof of address (housing contract)
Mobile banking (MTN Mobile Money, Airtel Money) is widely used - link it to your account
ATMs are widely available but may have withdrawal limits
Many places accept card payments, but carry some cash for smaller vendors

content.subtitle: Phone & Internet
tips: Get a local SIM card immediately at the airport or any MTN/Airtel shop
Recommended: MTN (better coverage) or Airtel (competitive rates)
Cost: ~$2-5 for SIM, ~$5-20/month for data plans
Campus has free WiFi, but having mobile data is essential
WhatsApp is the primary communication tool - everyone uses it

content.subtitle: Transportation
content.description: Getting around Kigali is easy and affordable.
tips: Moto-taxis (motorcycles): Fastest, $0.50-2 for most trips within city
Tap-Tap (ride-hailing app): Like Uber, safe and convenient
Yego Moto: App-based moto service with helmets provided
Public buses: Very cheap ($0.20-0.50) but can be crowded
Walking: Kigali is safe and walkable during the day
Campus shuttle: Free transport to/from main shopping areas on weekends

content.subtitle: Food & Dining
tips: Campus cafeteria: Affordable meals ($2-5), various options
Local restaurants: Try brochette, ugali, isombe (local dishes)
Supermarkets: Simba, Nakumatt, Carrefour for groceries
Delivery apps: Jumia Food, Glovo for restaurant delivery
Street food is generally safe and delicious - try the sambusas!
Vegetarian/vegan options are available but may require asking
Dining out: Budget $5-10 for local places, $10-25 for international restaurants

content.subtitle: Safety & Health
tips: Kigali is one of the safest capitals in Africa - low crime rate
However, stay aware of your surroundings, especially at night
Emergency numbers: Police 112, Ambulance 912
Campus clinic: Free basic healthcare for students
King Faisal Hospital: Recommended for serious medical issues
Health insurance is mandatory - make sure you're covered
Tap water is safe to drink in most areas
Malaria is rare in Kigali but take precautions if traveling outside the city

content.subtitle: Culture & Etiquette
tips: Kinyarwanda is the local language, but English is widely spoken
Learning basic Kinyarwanda phrases is appreciated: Mwaramutse (good morning), Murakoze (thank you)
Rwandans are generally friendly and helpful - don't hesitate to ask for help
Dress modestly, especially in rural areas
Plastic bags are banned - bring reusable bags for shopping
Umuganda: Community cleaning on last Saturday of each month (9am-11am) - participation encouraged
Smoking in public places is prohibited
Respect is important - greet elders and use polite language

content.subtitle: Things to Do
tips: Kimironko Market: Experience local market culture
Inema Arts Center: Contemporary Rwandan art
Kigali Genocide Memorial: Important historical site
Heaven Restaurant: Great views of the city
Nyamirambo Women's Center: Cultural tours and shopping
Lake Kivu: Weekend trip to relax by the beach (3 hours away)
Volcanoes National Park: Gorilla trekking (expensive but unforgettable)
Nightlife: Question Coffee, The Hut, Republic Lounge are popular spots

content.subtitle: Academic Support
tips: Office hours: Professors are very accessible - use them!
Peer tutoring: Free tutoring for core courses
Study groups: Join or form study groups early
Library: 24/7 access with great study spaces
Academic advisors: Meet regularly to stay on track

content.subtitle: Career Services
tips: Career counseling available for resume review, interview prep
Internship support: Help with finding summer opportunities
Industry connections: Regular tech talks and networking events
Alumni network: Active and willing to mentor

content.subtitle: Student Life
tips: Student clubs: Robotics, AI, entrepreneurship, sports, and more
Gym facilities: Free access to fitness center on campus
Counseling services: Free mental health support
Events: Hackathons, career fairs, cultural nights throughout the year
Student government: Get involved in campus decision-making

content.subtitle: Cost of Living
content.description: Kigali is relatively affordable compared to many capital cities.

expenses.notes: Depends on cooking vs. eating out

tips: Total monthly budget (excluding housing): $300-700 depending on lifestyle
Part-time work: Limited on-campus opportunities (TA, research assistant)
Scholarships and financial aid available - talk to student services

content.subtitle: Week 1 To-Do List
tasks: Attend orientation and get your student ID
Set up your university email and Canvas account
Get a local SIM card and phone number
Explore campus and locate your classrooms
Buy textbooks or find online resources
Learn the bus routes and transportation options
Find the nearest supermarket and ATM

conclusion: Remember, everyone goes through an adjustment period. Don't hesitate to reach out to current students, faculty, or staff if you need help. Welcome to the CMU Africa family! üéâ
